comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
This aint the "Brisbane Floods 1893" !!

Not 100% sure yet,  but I think it may be the SS 'Austral' (Orient Line) which sank in Neutral Bay whilst being loaded with coal.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Yes! The original photo was by John Paine in 1882 "Sinking of the S.S. Austral, Neutral Bay, New South Wales, 1882" (NLA nla.pic-vn4851231)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read all about it - SMH 13/11/1882 p.7 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13523253 .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The full story - www.nicholaseggleston.com/familyhistory/eggleston/Passeng... The salvage / re-floating operation was remarkable for any time, let alone 1882/3.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More about the photographer P.C. Poulsen (1857-1925). He moved from Sydney to Brisbane in 1882 - www.photo-web.com.au/poulsen/default.htm . I wonder why he made the film copy?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  Well spotted @beachcomber! The image is part of a collection of photographs of photographs. This one was in with 3 images of the Brisbane floods by Poulsen, obviously an extra in the collection. Will amend and update the records!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 28724605@N05
comment._content: Very interesting for me as I have a letter written by my great grandmother while aboard this ship enroute to NZ, dated 15th september 1882 - to her mother in England !

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mary_faith]  Wow that's a fantastic record to have Mary! Does the letter describe the event?!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 28724605@N05
comment._content:
The letter I have is very long and a beautifully written account of shipboard life -  the weather etc..  I can forward you a copy if you like - their names etc. Written late September, the letter was written before the sinking in November.
    Unfortunately I do not have last page(s) of the letter.:(
I have just read the 17 page comprehensive report on the sinking. Very interesting reading.
The passengers and cargo were unloaded prior to the sinking.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mary_faith] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mary_faith] Hi Mary - apologies for the late reply. We would love a copy of the letter for our records. If you have a transcript or copy please feel free to email at web@anmm.gov.au. Otherwise inbox us your details and we will contact you! Thanks again,  Penny (Curatorial assistant)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 68071043@N03
comment._content: my great grandmother travelled to Melbourne on the Austral arriving in October 1888 Mary Amelia Grossmith  Her brother travelled with her as a crew member  Thomas Grossmith another relative was the Ship Steward.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/68071043@N03] It is certainly a ship with a fascinating history, and with many stories attached. Thanks for sharing :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Another view of the shipwreck by Charles Bayliss - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.pic-vn5755616

comment.author: 37457215@N02
comment._content:
I wonder if any pictures show the Captain who was sent out to take command after she was raised
He was Alfred John Coad.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/37457215@N02] Couldn't find any images in our collection, however here is a later portrait of Capt Alfred J Coad in the Queensland Times, 28 March 1925.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 37457215@N02
comment._content:
Thank you so much !
I have done a bit of research on him over the years but never found a portrait. 
He finished as Senior Captain and Commodore. 

Very kind regards and good wishes from Scotland 
Fred

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/37457215@N02] Great! Glad the article was of some use, best wishes for your research :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 107091515@N07
comment._content:
Great story, now lets add to it. Can I email to you the photo's of John Madden and the news paper death certificate which discusses how he was the deep sea diver commissioned to salvage the sunken SS Austral. Our family legend is that John Madden Jnr was commissioned to retrieve gold bullion from the sunken ship. During the retrieval he unfortunately couldn't recover all of the gold. The story continues... from that date on, John apparently paid for all in slivers of gold... mmm. Following his death it was reported his remaining heirs converged onto his dwelling ( still standing in Balgownie) and excavated the site searching for his bounty.... sadly none was found.
Regards Martin
